ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual live lectures which were set up in a discussion-based format.
n/a
i think what i listed above is the only thing we did: seminar online

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A great introduction to analysing, reading and writing modern essays. The professor was very skilled and helped us learn techniques to recognize linguistic devices and themes in essays. A very eye-opening course from an English Language perspective.

I gained knowledge about different techniques used in personal essays and more generally learned more about writing and reading personal essays analytically, expanded on skills with being concise with language and conveying things in a creative way
This course improved my skills in the reading and construction of essays. I was also granted a greater arsenal of literary tools and taught to avoid cliches in my writing.
I learned how to read more closely.
How to write effectively
Writing succinct and impactful modern essays.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not a weakness as such, but turnovers between assignments can sometimes become a bit hectic, so perhaps the spacing of assignments could be improved.

Strengths: readings were well-chosen, liked reading other students' essays, discussions were super helpful with diving into material, workshops were super helpful with improving essays
Weaknesses: Professor didn't get back to us with feedback very quickly on our writing

I think the greatest strength of the course is the discussions that we had during lectures. These allowed us to learn from on another and improve our own writing by integrating the skills of our classmates and other well-known writers.

The only weakness would be that the turnover period between essays can be quite short at some points in the semester.
It was online. Maybe throwing in a creative project would have also been nice to switch things up instead of constantly writing essays for an entire semester.

The strengths of this course were the collaborative workshops and discussions about the readings done for the class. I think it could be improved by providing students with more guidance as in how to approach reading the pieces that are given as homework, with more insight into how students should think of the readings and the topics of the readings as they are consuming the content.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall not much more that could have been done given the circumstances. I'm satisfied with how everything was set up.
Nothing could've been improved as far as COVId
I think this class did very well to encourage engagement and the open structure of our discussion made it easy to give input.
They were all fine. Also the professor was very accomodating to all our schedules which definelty helped to relieve stress.

I think the practice that most succeeded during the pandemic was the organization of peer editing during collaborative workshops and how students engaged in an organized manner to edit their peers' essays. I think "instant" communication can be improved, if in any case it is possible to form a more accessible group chat with the class and the professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely, if you're interested in the English language or just want a writing credit, this is a great class to take. It really helps bring out the best writer and reader in you.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I thought it was a nice introduction to upper-level creative writing and the course structure lends itself to improvement in overall writing/reading

I would definitely recommend this course. Not only do you gain more tools from the writers you study but also from your peers. The opportunity to have others read your essay and provide feedback also proves itself invaluable and I felt a genuine improvement in my approach to writing through this course.

I would probably recommend depending on the person. If you like doing a lot of reading and writing then sure. It does feel a bit like a high school essay writing class if your course offered something like this. If you feel comfortable with reading and writing I would just jump to taking another more interesting elective right at the gate.
Definitely, it improved my writing exponentially.

I would recommend this course to another student because I think for me it was a course where I was free to express writing meaningful to my personal life throughout different concepts and frameworks, while also being exposed to that writing of others, experimenting with elements of writing I would otherwise feel uncomfortable using. I also think the collaboration this course brings is very improvement focused and a great way to develop new or sharpen writing skills.
